p.s: Lady Macbeth uses a particular choice of words and stilisticstylistic devices to convince her husband of murdering King Duncan.
First of all she is talking much more in this scene than her husband.
Macbeth talks just a few sentences, his wife speaks the most of the time.
In line nine she uses a rhetorical question: Was the hope drunk wherein you dressed yourself? to make fun about her husband and his hopes.
In line 19 she uses a metaphor like the poor cat i'the adage? in a rhetorical question.
She is saying with this metaphor that if he want to get or reach something he havehas to do something or work hard for it.
She wants to open his eyes that nothing in life comes by doing nothing and if he has a goal he must be prepared to make his hands dirty.
Macbeth is not with her.
He uses a metaphor in line 22 who dares do more is none to contradict her.
He just says doing less is sometimes doing more like sometimes you have to wait everything is happening time by time.
Lady Macbeth is absolutely other opinion.
She says what beast was't, then, that made you break this enterprise to me? with this choosing words she wants to stress out how important this enterprise was for her.
She wants to give him a bad feeling, like it is that important for her and he just says from one minute to the other he wants to do it other way.
She uses beast to make clear that the plan was so strong that just a beast could change his mind.
In this part (ll. 23-35) she tries many times giving his husband a bad feeling for example in line 32 to 35.
She names things she would do and sweared him to do it like he had sworn to her their enterprise.
By this Macbeth is becoming a little bit weak.
He asks if we should fail?.
By his question he seems unsure like standing between totwo choices.
First he was against his wifeswife's plan but now he relates her but is still not amused.
She is trying further and further with many manipulations and a go to plan (ll. 38-39) (ll. 41-45).
She plays their enterprise down and takes it for granted.
